Fig. 1 Schematic of synthesis of CPPILs as well as reference samples via simultaneous Friedel−Crafts alkylation and/or quaternization reaction. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 FT-IR spectra of DCX, Salen Mn, MIm, DCX-C, DCX-S, DCX-M, and CPPILs. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (A) TGA curves of CPPILs. (B) 13C NMR of CPPILs. Chiral porous poly(ionic liquid)s: Facile one-pot, one-step synthesis and efficient heterogeneous catalysts for asymmetric epoxidation of olefins Jixia Wang Resources Investigation Data curation Writing – original draft Yabing Tian Investigation Shiguo Zhang Supervision Yan Zhang Conceptualization Supervision Writing – review & editing ⁎ College of Materials Science and Engineering, Hunan University, Changsha 410082, Hunan, China College of Materials Science and Engineering, Hunan University Changsha Hunan 410082 China College of Materials Science and Engineering, Hunan University, Changsha 410082, Hunan, China. ⁎ Corresponding author. Ionic liquids are potential media/solvents for asymmetric synthesis when combined with chiral catalysts, while most reported catalysts are homogenous, making them difficult to separate from the reaction systems. Herein, chiral porous poly(ionic liquid)s (CPPILs) containing chiral salen Mn(III) complex have been successfully synthesized through a simple and one-pot route involving simultaneously occurred Friedel-Crafts alkylation and quaternization. These CPPILs possess large specific surface area, plentiful micro/meso-porosity, and abundant ionic active sites. Consequently, CPPILs can serve as highly efficient heterogeneous catalysts for asymmetric epoxidation of styrene. Excellent catalytic performance with yield of epoxides and enantiomeric excess value comparable with or even higher than that of the homogeneous system was achieved. The high catalytic activity can be further expanded to various substrates of unfunctionalized olefins. These catalysts are stable and could be recycled at least five times without significant loss of reactivity and enantioselectivity. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Ionic liquids Chiral Porous Asymmetric epoxidation Olefins 1 Introduction Owing to their unique features including negligible vapor pressure, high thermal stability, wide liquid temperature range, non-flammable nature, and the ability to readily dissolve many chemicals, ionic liquids (ILs) have attracted considerable attention, particularly for asymmetric synthesis [1–3]. It was reported that chiral cationic Ru-diamine complexes were air-stable in ILs and could efficiently catalyze the asymmetric hydrogenation of quinolines [4]. ILs can also enhance the air toleration of chiral cationic iridium complexes with chiral phosphinooxazoline ligands for enantioselective hydrogenation of imines [5]. The imidazolium-based IL moiety with special “ionophilicity” and polarity can also exert synergistic effects to stabilize and activate chiral salen Mn(III) complex, and prevent the degradation of the catalyst during epoxidation of olefins [6]. However, most ILs-involved asymmetric syntheses are homogeneous system, wherein ILs (or chiral ILs) serve as green solvents and/or catalysts [2]. In such cases, homogeneous catalytic complexes are difficult to separate from the reaction mixture and their inevitable loss often leads to a gradual decrease in the catalytic activity during reuse. An ideal solution to this issue is to “heterogenize” chiral IL catalysts by non-covalent immobilization and covalent grafting on various porous matrixes such as organic polymers and inorganic materials [7–11], so that the chiral heterogeneous catalysts can be easily separated by simple filtration or centrifugation. Nevertheless, most of the modified catalysts are less efficient than the corresponding homogenous catalysts, probably due to the low loading of immobilized chiral moiety on the heterogeneous catalysts and leaching of active species during the reaction [12]. Chiral poly(ionic liquid)s (CPILs), wherein the chiral catalytic functional groups are attached to the polymeric backbone of poly(ionic liquid)s (PILs), are promising heterogeneous catalysts for efficient asymmetric synthesis because of their intrinsically high densities of both ionic and chiral moieties. Unfortunately, the reported CPILs are nanoparticles lack of porous structure or have micropores, which results in insufficient accessible reactive centers or small pore size that cannot accommodate large reactant molecules [13–17]. Introducing pores into CPILs yields chiral porous poly(ionic liquid)s (CPPILs), which could address the above detrimental issues. As one special kind of porous poly(ionic liquid)s (PPILs), CPPILs with chiral ionic moieties in the polymeric frameworks are particularly attractive because of large surface areas, high thermal stabilities, diverse building blocks, and tunable porous structures [4]. Synthesis of such PILs materials, however, is generally complicated, as with that of PPILs. PPILs are typically obtained by hard or soft templates, with whole synthetic procedures involving several tedious steps, including synthesis of IL monomers, template preparation, infiltration of the template with the IL monomers, polymerization and cross-linking of the IL monomers, and template removal via caustic reagents [18,19]. As compared to PPILs, the synthesis of CPPILs requires additional introduction of bulky and chiral building block. This step not only complicates the overall synthetic procedures, but also reduces the pore size. For this reason, CPPILs are rarely reported up to date [4]. It is thus highly desirable to develop an efficient method to prepare CPPILs. Recently, Friedel-Crafts polymerization has proven to be a straightforward method for the synthesis of hyper-crosslinked porous polymers (HCPs) [20,21]. The highly porous structure and narrowly distributed porosity afford large surface area and accessible channels for dispersing active sites into the frameworks. However, HCPs usually have dominated micropores smaller than 2 nm, hence these polymers can only be used for gas adsorption and cycloaddition of CO2 [22–27]. The absence of large pores in HCPs restricts the mass transfer process and thus their direct application to organic synthesis and catalysis. In this work, we demonstrated a template-free, one-pot, and one-step method to synthesize CPPILs with mesoporous structure via Friedel-Crafts hyper-crosslinking reaction. As a proof-of-concept, chiral manganese (III) salen complex was used as a catalytic moiety to fabricate CPPILs and epoxidation of nonfunctional olefins was explored as a model reaction. Epoxidation of olefins is of great importance in the synthesis of chiral epoxides, which are widely used in the manufacture of chiral glycol derivatives via regioselective ring-opening or functional transfer reactions [28,29]. Chiral salen Mn(III) compounds are highly active and enantioselective catalysts for such epoxidation [30–32]. Our results showed that the presence of N-methylimidazole (MIm) and the corresponding ionic moiety could endow the obtained CPPILs with mesoporous structure and large specific surface area (up to 282 m2 g−1), which affords easy accessibility of the active sites and good transformation of the substrates. These CPPILs could serve as chiral heterogeneous catalysts to efficiently catalyze asymmetric epoxidation of unfunctionalized olefins. One of them, i.e., CPPIL-4, exhibits catalytic activity and enantioselectivity even higher than the homogeneous catalyst system. This catalyst can be recycled at least five times without obvious loss of activity. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Chemicals and materials (R, R)-cyclohexanediamine (98%), 1, 4-bis(chloromethyl)-benzene (DCX, 98%), salicylaldehyde (99%), N-methylimidazole (MIm, 99%), anhydrous iron (III) chloride (FeCl3, 99%), 1, 2-dichloroethane (99%), ethanol (99%), manganese acetate (98%), lithium chloride (LiCl, 99%), methanol (99.7%), styrene (99%), pyridine-N-oxide (PyNO, 98%), sodium hypochlorite (NaClO, active chlorine>5%), 1, 2-dichloro-naphthalene (>98%), dichloro-naphthalene (>98%), α-methyl styrene (99%), indene (99%), and dichloromethane (99%) were purchased from Tansoole, China. α-Methylstyrene (99%), Indene (99%), and 1,2-dihydronaphthalene (98%) were purchased from Aldin, China. All reagents were commercially available and used without further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of chiral salen ligand and metal complex The chiral salen ligand was synthesized as follows (for the scheme of synthesis, please refer to Fig. S1): (R, R)-cyclohexanediamine (5.6 mmol) and salicylaldehyde (11.2 mmol) were dissolved in 20 mL ethanol at room temperature. The obtained solution was stirred at 80 ℃ for 12 h and then cooled to room temperature. The resulted solid was filtered and washed with diethyl ether and dried in a vacuum, with yield higher than 95%. 1H NMR (CDCl3) (400 MHz): δ ppm 13.31 (s, 2H, OH), 8.28 (s, 2H, CH=N), 7.20–6.80 (d, 8H, Ar-H, J =2.0 Hz), 3.35–3.33 (m, 2H, C=NCH), 1.99–1.48 (m, 8H, cyclohexyl-H). In order to synthesize chiral metal complex, 11.2 mmol Mn(OAc)2∙4H2O in methanol was added into a solution of 5.6 mmol of chiral salen ligand in ethanol, and the reaction mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 4 h. Then, 33.6 mmol LiCl was added into the suspension, and the mixture was stirred at 50 ℃ for 4 h. After cooling down and filtration, a brown residue was obtained, which was washed with deionized water three times, and dried in a vacuum oven at 40 °C for 24 h, with yield higher than 95%. 2.3 Synthesis of CPPILs and PPIL-4 Chiral salen Mn(III) complex and MIm were selected as building blocks for Friedel-Crafts reaction, and the initial molar quantities of salen Mn, DCX, MIm, and FeCl3 were 1, 4, 1, and 7 mmol, respectively. The mixture was dissolved in 30 mL 1, 2-dichloroethane. After stirring, the mixture was refluxed at 80 °C for 24 h, the solid obtained after filtration was washed with methanol until the filtrate was clear, and then dried at 60 °C for 12 h. The obtained product was denoted as CPPIL-4, wherein 4 indicates the molar amount of DCX during hypercrosslinking. For comparison, CPPIL-3 and CPPIL-5 were synthesized by varying the molar amounts of DCX to 3, and 5 mmol, respectively. PPIL-4, as an achiral analog of CPPIL-4, is also synthesized as with CPPIL-4, except that the (R, R)-cyclohexanediamine was replaced with cyclohexanediamine in the salen ligand. 2.4 Synthesis of DCX-S For comparison, a reference sample was also synthesized by one-pot reaction of salen Mn, DCX, and FeCl3, with their initial molar amounts of 1, 4, and 7 mmol, respectively. The mixture was dissolved in 30 mL 1, 2-dichloroethane. The mixture was stirred and refluxed at 80 ℃ for 24 h, and the solid obtained after filtration was washed with methanol until the filtrate was clear, then dried at 60 ℃ for 12 h. The product was labeled as DCX-S. 2.5 Synthesis of DCX-C For comparison, a reference sample was also synthesized by one-pot reaction of DCX and FeCl3, with their initial molar amounts of 4 and 7 mmol, respectively. The mixture was dissolved in 30 mL 1, 2-dichloroethane. The mixture was stirred and refluxed at 80 ℃ for 24 h, the solid obtained after filtration was washed with methanol until the filtrate was clear, then dried at 60 ℃ for 12 h. The product was labeled as DCX-C. 2.6 Synthesis of DCX-M For comparison, a reference sample was also synthesized by one-pot reaction of MIm, DCX, and FeCl3, with their initial molar amounts of 1, 4, and 7 mmol, respectively. The mixture was stirred and refluxed at 80 ℃ for 24 h, the solid obtained after filtration was washed with methanol until the filtrate was clear, then dried at 60 ℃ for 12 h. The product was labeled as DCX-M. 2.7 Characterizations Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES, ICPA 7000 SERIES) was used to measure the content of Mn atoms in the samples. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were carried out on Vario EL III Elemental analyses. The specific surface area testing was performed by a volumetric adsorption analyzer (JW-BK200C, Beijing JWGB Sci. & Tech. Co., Ltd.) at 76. 2 K, and the corresponding pore size distribution (PSD) of the polymers was analyzed by the non-local density functional theory (NLDFT) method. The sample was treated under 80 ℃ nitrogen for 6 h. The morphologies of the samples were determined by Field emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi S-4800) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy with a spherical aberration corrector (HRTEM, Titan G2 60–300) equipped with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping. The atomic dispersion of Mn atoms was detected by Aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM (JEM-ARM200F). Solid-state 13C nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were collected by Bruker NEO WB 400 M. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were obtained on a Thermo Nicolet 5700 spectrometer using KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted with a Thermogravimetric Analyzer (Mettler TGA SDTA851) with a heating rate of 10 °C/min from 30 °C to 1000 °C under N2 atmosphere. X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS) data was collected by ECSALAB250Xi spectrometer with an Al Kα X-ray radiation for excitation, and the binding energy was corrected by C 1 s value of 284. 6 eV. Diffuse reflectance UV–vis spectra of the solid samples were recorded using a spectrophotometer with an integrating sphere using BaSO4 as the standard. 2.8 Enantioselective epoxidation of olefins Enantioselective epoxidation reactions of olefins were carried out using the following steps: First, 0.5 mmol olefins and 1 mmol PyNO were added into 3 mL dichloromethane containing 0.03 mmol catalyst (6 mol% of substrate, based on Mn content) at 0 ℃. Then 1.3 mL NaClO was added into the mixture and stirred at 0 ℃ for 40 min. The reaction product was determined by GC-2014 C gas chromatography (FID, HP19091g-B213 chiral capillary column (30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 µm)) with nitrogen as carrier gas and a flow rate of 30 mL/min. The ejector, detector, and oven temperature were set as 220, 200, and 80 °C, respectively. The retention time of styrene, R-configuration, and S-configuration olefins epoxide was detected as 5.75, 14.48, and 15.62 min, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of FT-IR As shown in Fig. 1, CPPILs were facilely constructed by one-pot and one-step reaction involving hyper-crosslinking reaction and quaternization. As one of the reactants, chiral salen Mn(III) complex containing two symmetric benzene structures can be readily embedded into the skeletons of CPPILs by reacting with DCX through Friedel-Crafts alkylation in the presence of FeCl3 as a Lewis catalyst. DCX as an external cross-linkers can be simultaneously self-condensed into crosslinked porous structure of the polymeric framework and co-condensed with salen Mn(III) complex via Friedel−Crafts alkylation. Meanwhile, DCX can be co-condensed with MIm via quaternization to form ionic units in situ. Note that the content of chiral and ionic moieties in CPPILs could be controlled by regulating the molar ratios between the three components, and the resulted samples are denoted as CPPIL-3, CPPIL-4, and CPPIL-5 depending on the relative content of DCX, as shown in Fig. 1. For comparison, a series of reference samples were also synthesized, e.g., DCX-S, which is obtained as with CPPIL-4 but without MIm, denotes non-ionic and hyper-crosslinked sample, while DCX-M and DCX-C are obtained by direct self-condensation of DCX with and without MIm, respectively. The obtained CPPIL products are insoluble in water and common organic solvents, such as ethanol, acetone, tetrahydrofuran, dimethyl sulfoxide, and N,N-dimethylformamide, which not only suggests the high-degree hyper-crosslinking, but also ensures their application as heterogeneous catalysts for separation and reuse. Their structures were investigated by FT-IR. As shown in Fig. 2, DCX monomer exhibits a strong vibrational band at 680 cm−1, which can be attributed to the stretching vibration of C-Cl bond [33]. However, this band is absent for all polymers including CPPILs, DCX-C, DCX-S, and DCX-M, which is an indication of the conversion of the chloromethylene groups during cross-linking [34]. Several characteristic bands attributed to salen Mn(III) complex such as 2865 cm−1 (CH2) and 1545 cm−1 (C-O) can be clearly observed in all CPPILs, confirming that the chiral catalytic moiety is incorporated into the polymeric networks [15,35]. However, the characteristic band of 1617 cm−1 (CH=N) of salen Mn(III) complex is overlapped by the vibrations of aromatic ring skeleton at 1619 cm−1 observed for DCX-C, DCX-M, and DCX-S. A close inspection of the IR spectra revealed that all salen Mn(III)-involved polymeric samples including CPPILs and DCX-S exhibit a new band around 1652 cm−1, which can be assigned to the CC (stretching) vibration of substituted aromatic ring of salen Mn(III). The relative intensity ratio between 1652 and 1617 cm−1 was found to decrease with increasing the initial molar ratio of DCX from 3 to 5. 3.2 TG and 13C NMR analyses TG analyses show that the residual mass of CPPILs at 1000 °C is above 60 wt% ( Fig. 3A), which indicates that these polymers are potential carbon precursors, according to our previous work [36–38]. The absolute value of the carbon residue increases with increasing the DCX content and thus the crosslinking degree, as can be seen from CPPIL-3 to CPPIL-5. Moreover, their initial decomposition temperatures were higher than 150 °C. Further comparison between CPPIL-4 and reference samples (DCX-S, DCX-C, and DCX-M) reveals that the substituted Salen Mn(III) moiety accounts for the relatively low thermal stability of CPPILs (Fig. S3). Solid-state 13C NMR was used to investigate the molecular structure of CPPILs. As can be seen from Fig. 3B, the 13C NMR spectrum of CPPIL-4 shows three main peaks at ca. 34, 128 and 135 ppm, which can be assigned as the carbon in the methylene linkers, the unsubstituted (i.e., hydrogen-bearing) aromatic carbons, and the substituted phenyl carbons [26,39], respectively. The peak intensity ratio between 135 and 128 ppm, denoted as S/NS, can be used to semi-quantitatively describe the ratio of the substituted and non-substituted aromatic carbons in the polymeric structure [39]. With increasing the relative content of DCX in the precursor mixture, the calculated S/NS increased from 1.03 for CPPIL-3–1.18 for CPPIL-4 and 1.22 for CPPIL-5. This result suggests that the number of substituted aromatic carbons for all CPPILs is on average higher than that of non-substituted carbons; that is, an indication of a highly condensed network structure. Meanwhile, higher content of DCX leads to more substituted aromatic carbons because of its self-condensation. 3.3 XPS and ICP analyses The chemical compositions of CPPILs were analyzed by XPS and elemental analysis. As shown in Fig. 3C, C, N, O, Cl, and Mn can be detected in the survey XPS spectra. As for the high-resolution Mn 2p XPS spectrum (inset in Fig. 3C), the major peaks at the binding energy of 641.3 and 653.3 eV correspond to Mn 2 P3/2 and Mn 2 P1/2, respectively, which are in accordance with the reported values for salen Mn (III) complex [40,41]. The N 1s XPS spectrum can be deconvoluted into two distinct peaks, the peak around 398.7 eV is related to the imine-like (—N＝) from the salen moiety, while the peak at 401.1 eV is attributed to the imidazolium moiety (Fig. 3D) [27,41,42]. Table 1 listed the content of Mn in CPPILs determined by ICP and the contents of C and N determined by elemental analysis. It is obvious that the C contents (79.26–81.45%) are higher than the theoretical values (68.98–73.91%), suggesting that the hyper-crosslinking reaction is dominated by self-condensation of DCX cross-linkers because of its much higher activity than other components [43]. With increasing the relative content of DCX, the Mn contents and thus the contents of chiral salen Mn(III) unit decrease from 0.61 mmol/g for CPPIL-3–0.42 mmol/g for CPPIL-4 and 0.25 mmol/g for CPPIL-5. The corresponding N contents decrease from 2.27% to 1.85% and 1.77%, that is, 1.62 mmol/g for CPPIL-3, 1.29 mmol/g for CPPIL-4, and 1.25 mmol/g for CPPIL-5. The molar contents of N are obviously higher than the twice of molar contents of Mn, revealing the successful introduction of both chiral salen Mn(III) and IL units into the polymeric skeleton of CPPILs by Friedel-Crafts alkylation and quaternization. The contents of IL unit can be calculated by the expression of [N content (mmol/g) - 2 ×Mn content (mmol/g)]/2, which are 0.20, 0.25, and 0.37 mmol/g for CPPIL-3, CPPIL-4, and CPPIL-5, respectively. These results revealed that with increasing the relative ratio of DCX, the contents of salen Mn(III) decreases, while the contents of IL unit slightly increases. 3.4 BET analyzes The pore structures of CPPILs were analyzed by nitrogen adsorption-desorption test. As shown in Fig. S4A, the N2 sorption isotherms of all CPPILs can be assigned to the combination of Type-I and Type-IV profiles, according to IUPAC (International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry) classification [44]. The N2 capacity displayed a sharp increase at a relatively low pressure (P/P0 < 0.03), suggesting plentiful micropores. The obvious rise of the N2 isotherms at a medium pressure (0.3 < P/P0 < 0.9) indicates the presence of mesoporous structure. The sharp capillary condensation at relatively higher pressures (P/P0 = 0.6–0.9) indicated the presence of large mesopores and macropores. With increasing the DCX content, the specific surface area (S BET) of CPPILs increases from 189 m2/g for CPPIL-3–211 m2/g for CPPIL-4 and 282 m2/g for CPPIL-5, and correspondingly, the total pore volume (V tot) continuously increases from 0.265 to 0.269 and 0.372 cm3 g−1 (Table 1). This is not unexpected since DCX as an efficient cross-linker tends to form porous structure via simultaneous self-condensation, co-condensation with salen Mn(III) complex, and quaternization reaction with MIm, as mentioned above. A higher content of DCX is responsible for higher degree of cross-linking and thus larger SBET in the FeCl3-catalyzed Friedel-Crafts alkylation reaction. In fact, DCX-C obtained by direct self-condensation of DCX monomers exhibits a very large S BET of 1281 m2/g, very close to the reported values [39,45]. The micro-/mesoporous structure was verified by the corresponding pore size distribution (PSD) calculated by NLDFT method (Fig. S4B). It was found that self-condensation of DCX mainly results in micropores centered at around 1.5 nm, and the presence of MIm does not obviously change the PSD, as observed from DCX-C and DCX-M. However, the presence of salen Mn(III) moiety is liable to form abundant mesopores distributed from 2.5 to 30 nm in CPPILs, possibly due to the large molecular volume of this complex. Unlike the negligible effect of MIm on the porous structure (DCX-C vs DCX-M), DCX-S obtained by co-condensation of DCX monomer with bulky salen Mn(III) moiety possesses a very small S BET of 76 m2/g. Therefore, MIm is an essential building block to fabricate CPPILs with highly developed porous structure in the presence of chiral catalytic moiety. 3.5 Characterization of SEM and TEM The apparent porous structures of CPPILs were further revealed by SEM and TEM ( Fig. 4A-C). SEM images showed that CPPIL-4 is composed of flower-like structures with diameter of < 2 µm, which are assembled by a large number of nanosheets with an average thickness of ∼40 nm. TEM image of CPPIL-4 is quite translucent owing to its highly porous texture, displaying that abundant micropores were uniformly distributed in these nanosheets. It should be noted that the flower-like structures together with nanosheets makes the micropores nicely accessible from the outside. We also performed Aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC HAADF-STEM) to provide direct information on the location of heavy atoms, here the Mn atomic columns. A number of bright spots (red circles) in a size at atomic scale are well dispersed in the porous structure in CPPIL-4 without noticeable metal atom aggregation, conﬁrmed the isolated single metal atoms (Fig. 4D). However, because CPPIL-4 is a highly cross-linked sample and not very thin and flat as common 2D materials, the thickness and defocus would affect the brightness of Mn atoms, particularly in the central part of the HAADF image (Fig. 4D). EDS elemental mapping images of CPPIL-4 displayed that C, N, O, Cl, and Mn are uniformly distributed throughout the polymer framework (Fig. 4E), suggesting the good dispersion of both salen Mn(III) complex and IL units in the polymer framework. 3.6 Catalytic performance test fx1 . Because of the incorporated chiral salen Mn(III) moiety and ionic unit as well as their relative large surface area and abundant mesoporous structure, the obtained CPPILs are expected to be potential heterogeneous catalysts for asymmetric epoxidation of olefins. The catalytic experiments were carried out at 273 K using 6 mol% catalysts (based on Mn element) in the presence of NaClO/PyNO as an oxidant. The obtained results are listed in Table 2. Obviously, homogeneous system catalyzed by chiral salen Mn(III) complex could lead to quantitative conversion with selectivity of styrene epoxide and ee (enantiomeric excess) value of 97% and 37%, respectively (Table 2, entry 7), which is consistent with the reported values [46,47]. However, the reaction cannot be catalyzed by DCX-C and DCX-C despite their very large S BET (Table 2, entries 5–6), confirming that the presence of salen Mn (III) moiety is a perquisite for efficient asymmetric epoxidation of styrene. In fact, PPIL-4, as an achiral analog of CPPIL-4, is also synthesized as with CPPIL-4, except that the (R, R)-cyclohexanediamine was replaced with cyclohexanediamine. As expected, the enantioselectivity for asymmetric epoxidation of styrene is nearly zero, in spite that it shows high conversion (98%) and selectivity (97%) comparable with CPPIL-4. DCX-S containing chiral catalytic moieties could result in 93% selectivity and 41% ee (enantiomeric excess) value (Table 2, entry 4), while the obtained conversion is as low as 47%, which is undoubtedly ascribed to its very small S BET and thus less exposed active sites and limited mass transfer ability. The absence of MIm monomer and thus ionic unit in the polymeric framework could be another reason [26]. When using CPPILs as heterogeneous catalysts, significant improvement in conversion of epoxidation of unfunctionalized olefins while keeping the high selectivity and ee value is achieved (Table 2, entries 1–3). Particularly, CPPIL-4 gives rise to the best catalytic performance, with both conversion and selectivity close to 99% and ee of 41%. This performance is even better than the homogeneous system catalyzed by chiral salen Mn(III) complex. The excellent performance of CPPIL-4 could be ascribed to the relatively large S BET, high content of Mn and ionic unit, and particularly, hierarchical flower-like and nanosheet-containing structure with developed mesopores. The catalytic performances of CPPILs were further compared with other chiral salen Mn(III) complex-supported catalysts under similar reaction conditions [46,48,49]. As seen from Table 3, chiral salen Mn(III)-supported MCM-48 showed only 35% of yield and 32% of enantioselectivity (Table 3, entry 6). When the porous matrix was changed into MCM-41, the yield and enantioselectivity increase to 91% and 37%, respectively (Table 3, entry 7), however, still much lower than that of CPPIL-4 in this work (Table 3, entry 2). Among all CPPILs, CPPIL-4 exhibited the highest yield and turnover frequency (TOF). Particularly, its TOF is as high as 6.8 (10−3 s−1), which is twice of the solvent-regulated phase transfer catalyst, that is, polymeric chiral salen Mn 3 reported by tan et al. (Table 3, entry 4) [46]. CPPIL-4 also exhibited excellent catalytic activity towards various substrates of unfunctionalized olefins, including α-methylstyrene, indene, and 1, 2-dihydronaphthalene. As shown in Table 4, high conversion (93%) and ee value (39%) was achieved in the asymmetric epoxidation of a-methylstyrene. For relatively bulky olefins, such as indene and 1, 2-dihydronaphthalene, moderate conversion (75% and 77%) and good ee values (89% and 99%) were obtained (Table 4, entries 3 and 4). To study the stability and reusability of CPPIL catalysts, the recycling experiments were carried out with catalyst CPPIL-4 using styrene as a mode substrate. After each experiment, the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by simple filtration, washed, and dried before using it in the subsequent run. As depicted in Fig. 5, this catalyst could be reused up to five times with no significant loss in activity. The conversion, selectivity, and enantioselectivity only slightly reduced to 97%, 96%, and 37%, respectively. 4 Conclusions In summary, CPPILs were synthesized by a facile, one-pot reaction involving chiral salen Mn(III) complex, DCX and MIm, for which quaternization and Friedel-Crafts alkylation occur simultaneously to generate porous and hypercrosslinked polymer skeleton in situ. The obtained CPPILs possess large surface area and micro/mesoporous structure, which together with chemical composition can be adjusted by regulating the molar ratios of the three reactants. Note that MIm is essential to fabricate CPPILs with highly developed porous structure in the presence of bulky catalytic moiety. CPPILs as porous and heterogenous catalysts are highly efficient for asymmetric epoxidation of olefins. Particularly, CPPIL-4, which possesses a relatively large S BET, high content of Mn and ionic unit, hierarchical structure, and developed mesopores, can nearly quantitatively convert styrene to styrene epoxide with both conversion and selectivity close to 99% and ee of 41%. The obtained catalytic performance is even better than that catalyzed by homogeneous chiral salen Mn(III) complex. This novel heterogeneous catalyst also has an excellent catalytic activity towards various substrates of unfunctionalized olefins and can be re-used at least five times without significant loss of activity, indicating that the one-step polymerization procedure was effective and led to the stabilization of the salen Mn(III) species during catalysis. The present strategy may offer a new platform for designing chiral porous poly(ionic liquid)s for advanced applications such as enantioseparation and chiral resolution. coredata.dc:description: Ionic liquids are potential media/solvents for asymmetric synthesis when combined with chiral catalysts, while most reported catalysts are homogenous, making them difficult to separate from the reaction systems. Herein, chiral porous poly(ionic liquid)s (CPPILs) containing chiral salen Mn(III) complex have been successfully synthesized through a simple and one-pot route involving simultaneously occurred Friedel-Crafts alkylation and quaternization. These CPPILs possess large specific surface area, plentiful micro/meso-porosity, and abundant ionic active sites. Consequently, CPPILs can serve as highly efficient heterogeneous catalysts for asymmetric epoxidation of styrene. Excellent catalytic performance with yield of epoxides and enantiomeric excess value comparable with or even higher than that of the homogeneous system was achieved. The high catalytic activity can be further expanded to various substrates of unfunctionalized olefins. These catalysts are stable and could be recycled at least five times without significant loss of reactivity and enantioselectivity.
coredata.dc:title: Chiral porous poly(ionic liquid)s: Facile one-pot, one-step synthesis and efficient heterogeneous catalysts for asymmetric epoxidation of olefins
